description: Adverse event that lead to treatment discontinuation
Adverse event that lead to dose interruption
Adverse event that lead to dose reduction
Adverse event is reported as dose-limiting toxicity for the drug
Clinically administered drug has effect on target-related biomarker
DDI was measured by co-administration with probe substrate
Protein expression measurement in tissues from patients who administered the drug
DDI was measured by studying effect of target genotype variation on the drug PK parameters
Effect of the drug on QT interval was measured in clinics
No experiments were conducted, but PK modeling suggests clinical relevance of interactions
Clinical experiments were conducted and no evidence supporting the interaction was found
Clinical experiments are ongoing, no results were published
No experiments were conducted, but PK modeling suggests lack of clinical relevance
Clinical experiments were conducted and no weak evidence supporting the interaction was found (probe drugs exposure increase <1.5x or decrease to >0.67x)
Clinical experiments were conducted and found that interaction has clinical relevance
Drug doesn't interact with a target
Drug strongly interacts with a target (major substrate, strong/clinically relevant inhibitor or inducer)
Drug weakly interacts with a target
Drug binds to a target, but no information about its effect is available
Drug induces target expression and activity
Drug is a substrate of a target
Drug supresses expression of a target
Dosing regimen is complex (e.g. several routes of administration are combined)
Arithmetic mean dose (across time, or across population)
Median dose (across time or across population)
A middle point of a dose range
Minimal dose (typically actual dose is larger)
Total dose administered per time period
Patients from several studies were pooled; typical dose is reported
The dosage is unknown; there is no other data
Dose which was adminstered by drug abusers
Dose was administered by accident, by a non-recommended settings (e.g. intravenous drug administered intrathecally)
The dose is highest studied dose at a given route of administration

Minimum effective dose - the lowest dose level of a pharmaceutical product that provides a clinically significant response in average efficacy, which is also statistically significantly superior to the response provided by the placebo.
Maximum tolerated dose - the highest dose of a treatment that will produce the desired effect without unacceptable toxicity

The dose was used in the study, without indication about whether the dose is recommended
Drug concentration in applied formulation (e.g. for topical administration when total mass of administered drug is unknown)
Total exposure - drug concenration times the duration of administration
Nutrient is administered with food, dose is calculated relative to the total caloric input

The assumed average maintenance dose per day for a drug used for its main indication in adults.
Investigational dose (used when no other information is available)
Maximum tolerated dose - the highest dose of a treatment that will produce the desired effect without unacceptable toxicity.

Minimum effective dose - the lowest dose level of a pharmaceutical product that provides a clinically significant response in average efficacy, which is also statistically significantly superior to the response provided by the placebo.

No Observed Adverse Effect Level - An exposure level at which there are no statistically or biologically significant increases in the frequency or severity of adverse effects between the exposed population and its appropriate control; some effects may be produced at this level, but they are not considered as adverse, or as precursors to adverse effects.
